I turned it off and left it for a while thinking maybe it was just the fan burning a little bit of off gassing, but even later when i turned it on within second the same smell was produced and again i found it irritating to my lungs. Even though they are a hard sell on having no Ozone it is not zero. So perhaps in this case there is something happening here that is causing this reaction, this smell. I can't say exactly what. Either it is off-gassing, producing ozone, electrical burning smell from the fan or something else i'm not aware of. All this to say i was quite disappointed and am now very skeptical to the Polar-ionization technology being as clean as they mention

The unit has very limited control. It operates when it wants to and there is no ability for the user to override the automatic features. It should allow the user to simply turn the unit on or off and set a desired fan speed. It does not allow thus fundamental feature. The app is completely useless. It does not provide real-time status of the unit so when you're travelling you cannot tell what mode it is operating in or that it is operating at all. The child lock is also useless. You can activate the child lock at bedtime, but sometime during the night, the lock will always turn itself off. The control panel will then illuminate your bedroom and change fan speeds depending on what it appears to sense in the air even though the app says air quality is at its best. So the relatively quiet, low speed fan becomes a louder medium to high speed fan. This madenling misfunction does not make for a good night's sleep. There needs to be a bedtime mode or manual mode where the fan speed will never go above low. Lastly, the scheduler function is inadequate. You can set multiple periods for the unit to operate, but typically the unit may turn on at the scheduled time (most of the time), but it hardly ever shuts off when scheduled. Even when it does shut off, it often will turn itself back on at a time for which it is not scheduled to operate. This and the other deficiencies already mentioned essentially eliminates all user flexibility for controlling the operation of the unit. So the bottom line is that the unit probably does a decent job at cleaning indoor air, but do not expect any ability to manually control the unit in any substantial way. I understand changes are in development, but frankly this system is not ready for distribution and should not have been sold in its current limited capacity.

Review.Titre: Replacement part may be fine , but

Even has 3 nice pics showing reset button locations for various models and the time frames they were built.  Mine has no reset button anywhere . One this gets resolved , or otherwise , I can update this review . I don’t think it will take much to get it to a 5-star review , time will tell ,…    Well , it’s update time .   The unit is too old to be covered under warranty and the replacement parts won’t work on this “older model” , but good news,…  all units are on sale this month !!!!  😏 I don’t know if these things are worth every penny or not worth a bent nickel as far as doing the job they claim to do , but I do know they are very expensive . When it comes to replacement parts needed at $120 ea. ever 2 years , I feel they are closer to the bent nickel value . I’ve been trying to repair these again , (been about 2 years since last time) for friends. Kinda stinks to go through all the haste only to find out that it’s nothing more than a terrible boat anchor . The costumer service is pretty good , fast actually , and pleasant as well . The product durability/lifespan is weak .  Not a fan for the long haul of these .

The filters need to be changed much more frequently than other similar air purifiers I have. I think one reason is they do not use even the most basic pre-filter and the intake is directly to the HEPA. This makes it fill up with just household dust rapidly. A pre-filter would save a lot of money like it does on every other machine I have and seen no matter how inexpensive the machine. It seems the only reason is to sell more filters? Also if you are chemically sensitive (one reason for a filter) the materials used to manufacture the filters outgas and have VOC's so they require 5-14 days of detoxing before I can even be in the same room as the filter. Why not use safe non-voc etc for a filter that is to clean the air?

That one unfortunately always has a lot of bright lights so I had to stick something on top of the machine since I don’t like bright lights in my bedroom at night. I also placed it in the same spot as my old air purifier I replaced and I’ve noticed that this one is less effective at removing smells from the litter box. I think it may be from where the air is coming in and it’s placement, but it is a bit disappointing that I have it running and it often still smells. The old one was taller and seemed more effective. I hope these are working as well as they say they do but based on how it’s handling smells I imagine it’s not clearing out all the viruses in the air (Covid just went through the house despite having this running constantly and others in other rooms) and mold that effectively either then. Review.Titre: Seem to be working but slow....
Review.Contenu: I recently bought two of the Ionic air models to assist in VOC and mold neutralization left over from remediation activities. I set them up around 8pm, one in my office for the evening and one in the living area. House is a single floor with basement furnace return air, fan set to on for constant circulation in the house.These units are very small with low flow rates and are not meant to be whole house treatment devices, only room specific for most commonly occupied areas.As of 8:30 pm the tvoc meter in my office was reading 1.239 mg/m3, current reading as of 2:01am is 1.07 mg/m3. No ventilation to the outside. Only natural aspiration via dryer/bathroom vent or air leaks.House is 1035 sqft so take that x2 ( for the open basement space all return air goes into ) then x8 for typical residential ceiling height = 16560 cuft (468.93 m3). The fans in these units are Noctua fans rated for 53.3 m3/hr. To treat the entire volume of my house once requires ~8.8 hrs using a single unit. Current spec is for max 660 sqft ( 5280 ft3 or 2.8 hr for 1 air change per space at unit flow rate ) and minimum of 100 sqft well ventilated for ozone safety ( 800 ft3 or 26min for 1 air change per space at unit flow rate )So real world use case: With that in mind, if you want to neutralize VOCs like say what Karen D left in her prior comment ( Acetone in nail polish remover for instance), using a few cotton swabs, the surface area of a nail, maybe a few tissues too that further add to surface area you're allowing said solvent to diffuse from, don't expect the purifier to magically cut the odor in a small time frame. Be realistic here.... it's not designed for that kind of fast removal activity. You would need a huge amount of catalyst surface area and airflow to keep up with the diffusion rate of such substances.Much more practical solution would be employing adequate mechanical negative ventilation to the outside in said affected space than trying to rely on an air purifier to do the job of fresh air replacement. Things like these are more of a final polish device that will pick up anything you haven't captured via another HEPA, carbon capture, germicidal UV sterilization or mechanical ventilation. So when buying these have realistic expectations to where and on what you are using it for.For me, they are doing what I need them to do at a slow rate but that's fine as it will meet target when I need it to based on the meter reading.For anyone worried about the negligible amount of ozone generated by these I setup a test using a calibrated Eco Sensors Model C-30Z Ozone monitor placed 18 inches from the unit on the end table in my office. Turned off my HVAC system for the night at 8:30 pm and closed the door. The room size is 9ft x 8.7 ft or 78.3 sq ft, well under their minimum room size and certainly not well ventilated with the door shut.Left it in this state until my morning alarm at 7am. The ozone monitor hadn't moved from the bottom indicator of the range which would be .02 ppm. However I could certainly smell it in the space.The human olfactory sensitivity is 0.003 – 0.015 ppm depending on your particular biology. So you will likely smell it before any monitoring device indicates elevated exposure levels above the normal 0.01 ppm natural background levels you would expect to find out in the country side away from industrial areas and citys. EPA current exposure limits for ground-level ozone is 0.070 ppm, averaged over an 8-hour period. AQI Value | Ozone Level (ppm)Good 0-50 | 0.000-0.054Moderate  51-100 | 0.055-0.070Unhealthy for sensitives	                   101-150 | 0.071-0.085Unhealthy   151-200 | 0.086-0.105Hazardous  201-300 | 0.106-0.200The breakpoint for “good” air quality is 0.054, which converts to about 0.106 mg/m³, about the same as the WHO’s recommended limit of 0.1 mg/m³.But based on the simple real world check above, do I think it will increase the ozone in my house to dangerous levels...not likely...but you can take that how you want. Every home's outdoor air exchange rates are different so if you have a very tight home....maybe...but it's going to take a long time to do it. Want to know for sure, buy your own monitor. Alot of other equipment in your house also generates Ozone (TVs, hair dryers, etc).

Review.Titre: Decent Air Purifiers, Fair Warranty Process
Review.Contenu: ** UPDATE: 5/3/2022 **Within hours after posting our initial review, AirOasis reached out and offered to send replacement UV-C bulbs at no cost to us.  In fact, the bulbs arrived only a few days after our review posted.  The bulbs were easy to install and restored our air purifiers to perfect working condition.  Two representatives followed-up with us to make sure our concerns were fully addressed; they greatly appreciated us taking the time to share our feedback and they acted promptly to make things right.  Given that the company responded promptly and took such good care to remedy our problem, we recommend AirOasis and their iAdaptAir purifiers; the units are making a noticeable difference in our air quality in our home.  We know the company stands behind their products and wants to please their customers before *and* after the sale.--- Original Review ---Our family is a little disappointed in our experience with Air Oasis.  The iAdaptAir purifiers have respectable technology built-in, however, after only a few months of using two of their "large" units, we experienced problems with three UV-C lamps burning out (one lamp on the one unit, two lamps on the other).  The customer service reps were extremely friendly and courteous to deal with, however, the warranty policy is not as customer-centric as we had hoped.  Instead of shipping out replacement UV-C lamps (or potentially whole new units) upfront, the company makes you first ship the two large purifiers back to them at the CUSTOMER'S expense (quite costly as these are a few feet tall and rather heavy), then wait for a "credit" to be applied to your Air Oasis account (once the company receives the tracking #s for the original units being sent back).  The customer can then purchase brand new units to be shipped using the "credit" applied to the account by Air Oasis.Our biggest issue with this process is having to absorb the large expense and hassle of shipping the "faulty" units back, along with the delay time  turning everything around; we have a frustrating mold problem in our home we're trying to get ahead of and these filters have mitigated our allergies to a certain degree.  We don't want to be without (partially) functioning units for an extended period as we wait for the replacement units.  Also, we disposed of the original shipping/product boxes months ago; finding boxes and packing materials to ship these rather odd-shaped machines back is a challenge.  Additionally only the UV-C lamps were problematic, the rest of the units were fine... why be forced to return both of the purifiers themselves?  The company should design the machines for easy swap-out of the UV-C bulbs by the customer as they need to be replaced periodically anyway.We feel Air Oasis should send replacement units to the customer upfront, along with pre-paid labels to have the defective units sent back.  This allows the customer to keep the partially functioning filters running as they wait for the replacements, then the customer can slip the defective units into the new boxes from the replacement units afterward.  If customer fails to send the original units back, Air Oasis can reserve the right to charge customer for the replacement units (via a credit card on file).  Better still, simply send out inexpensive replacement UV-C bulbs for the customer to replace at their convenience.  This makes for a much better warranty process overall.  It also demonstrates Air Oasis' commitment to the customer and their willingness to stand behind their products, especially "high end" models like these.Lastly, these air purifiers are NOT inexpensive... these are the company's "flagship" home air purifiers and the large models we purchased were around $600 per unit with replacement filters costing just under $100.  The company should make any warranty claims easier and less expensive for customers who shell out this much money upfront for a quality, state-of-the-art product.  Having UV-C bulbs last much longer than a few months on two different units, would be a bonus as well.We hope this review helps others make informed decisions about doing business with Air Oasis.  We will continue to use these partially-functioning units for awhile (with diminished UV-C purification) and look to other companies in the future for alternative air purifier purchases.
